symptoms.name: Dysphagia
symptoms.pattern: Associated with larger tumors causing obstruction

symptoms.name: Obstructive jaundice
symptoms.pattern: Associated with larger tumors causing obstruction

symptoms.name: Constipation
symptoms.pattern: Associated with larger tumors causing obstruction

symptoms.name: Indolent or massive intraperitoneal bleeding
symptoms.pattern: Secondary to pressure necrosis and ulceration

symptoms.name: Gastrointestinal bleeding
symptoms.pattern: May present as acute bleed with melena or hematochezia, or chronic bleeding with anemia

imaging_findings.CT scan: Contrast-enhancing mass with smooth margins;  can identify location, perforation, invasion, metastasis
imaging_findings.Abdominal ultrasound: Useful if tumor >5cm, but reliability affected by necrosis, ulceration, air, operator expertise
imaging_findings.MRI: Alternative to CT if contrast is contraindicated
imaging_findings.PET: Mentioned as a modality for imaging, but details not specified
imaging_findings.Endoscopy: Subendothelial lesions; smooth bulge covered with normal mucosa
imaging_findings.Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS): Hypoechoic solid mass originating from second (muscularis mucosa) or fourth (muscularis propria) layers of GI tract wall

required: Morphologic findings consistent with GIST on hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) staining
Immunohistochemical testing positive for KIT (95% of cases), or DOG-1 and CD34 if KIT is negative
supportive: Imaging findings (CT, MRI, ultrasound, EUS) showing a mass consistent with GIST
